Abstract:

This work presents an autoregressive generative diffusion model (DiffObs) to predict the global evolution of daily precipitation, trained on a satellite observational product, and assessed with domain-specific diagnostics. The model is trained to probabilistically forecast day-ahead precipitation and is stable for multi-month rollouts, revealing a qualitatively realistic superposition of convectively coupled wave modes in the tropics. Cross-spectral analysis confirms the successful generation of low-frequency variations associated with the Madden-Julian oscillation and convectively coupled moist Kelvin waves with approximately correct dispersion relationships. Despite secondary issues and biases, the results affirm the potential for a next-generation global diffusion model trained on increasingly sparse and direct observations for practical applications in subseasonal and climate prediction.

Introduction:

As machine learning-driven global forecasting systems move beyond weather timescales toward climate timescales, it becomes an important question whether they can generate realistic convectively coupled tropical disturbances across daily to multi-week simulations. Such atmospheric variability has been a longstanding challenge to capture realistically in physics-based models and is still incompletely understood, yet regulates the subseasonal predictability of the Earth System, including tropical to extratropical teleconnections. Emerging autoregressive diffusion models learn conditional probabilities and are well-suited to the stochastic character of tropical convective dynamics. These methods suggest that diffusion models do not require complete information about the atmospheric state and may produce realistic variability even when trained on limited, direct observations.

We introduce a computationally ambitious, high-resolution global autoregressive diffusion model trained solely on a satellite-derived precipitation product. Precipitation is observed globally via microwave sensing satellites, and prior low-order models have proven skillful at long-range forecasts. The coupling of data and our modeling approach is pivotal to the feasibility of our current work. Using our trained model, we perform an in-depth analysis of generated tropical variability on 1- to 60-day timescales using domain-informed diagnostics, discovering long-term stability with realistic variability of multiple wave structures.

Methodology:

We introduce an autoregressive diffusion model, extending the EDM architecture, with the objective to estimate p(xt|xt−1) without incorporating additional priors. Our model assumes a paired spatiotemporal relationship within the underlying distribution to effectively capture the dynamics of the system based solely on the immediate past state. The design specifics of our model are inspired by prior global diffusion-based weather forecasting models. We build upon the work of Mardani et al. (2024), which employs a similar architecture for km-scale downscaling, but avoid the use of an intermediate regression model and do not scale down the conditional inputs.

Training Details:

Our experiments use the default hyperparameters outlined in Karras et al.
